questions: [{"id": 1, "text": "One of the brain's most difficult tasks is to", "correctAnswer": "react to their own thoughts"}, {"id": 2, "text": "Because of the language they have developed, humans", "correctAnswer": "create a mental shift"}, {"id": 3, "text": "Individual responses to humour", "correctAnswer": "are personal and unpredictable"}, {"id": 4, "text": "Peter Derks believes that humour", "correctAnswer": "is a form of creative insight"}]
passageContent: ["The joke comes over the headphones: 'Which side of a dog has the most hair? The left.' No, not funny. Try again. 'Which side of a dog has the most hair? The outside.' Hah! The punchline is silly yet fitting, tempting a smile, even a laugh. Laughter has always struck people as deeply mysterious, perhaps pointless. The writer Arthur Koestler dubbed it the luxury reflex: 'unique in that it serves no apparent biological purpose'. Theories about humour have an ancient pedigree. Plato expressed the idea that humour is simply a delighted feeling of superiority over others. Kant and Freud felt that joke-telling relies on building up a psychic tension that is safely punctured by the ludicrousness of the punchline. But most modern humour theorists have settled on some version of Aristotle's belief that jokes are based on a reaction to or resolution of incongruity when the punchline is either nonsense or, though appearing silly, has a clever second meaning. Graeme Ritchie, a computational linguist in Edinburgh, studies the linguistic structure of jokes in order to understand not only humour but language understanding and reasoning in machines."]
passageSubtitle: John McCrone reviews recent research on humour
